intro: Myrceugenia pilotantha var. major, commonly known as the large-flowered myrtle, is a species native to the temperate regions of South America, particularly in Chile. It is a shrub or small tree that typically grows to a height of 3–5 meters, featuring dense, glossy, dark green leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in late spring or early summer, followed by edible, dark purple berries. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for cultivation in gardens and landscapes. Its ornamental value and aromatic properties make it a valued plant in both horticulture and traditional medicine.
